Paper name: BioWeave: Weaving Thread-Based Sweat-Sensing On-Skin Interfaces
venue: ACM UIST (User Interface Software and Technology)
Sensing Target: sweat pH
Type of sensing: Colorimetric (optical)
Substrate: Woven textile
Substrate sourcing: Commercial weaving yarns (e.g., mercerized perle cotton 10/2 and 20/2 from Woolery; general yarns from Amazon/Woolery)
Sensing layer materials: Colorimetric assays (from urinalysis/pH/glucose test strips)
Sensing materials Sourcing: Colorimetric strips (Amazon, Just Fitter, Bayer Diastix)
Fabrication process: Dyeing cotton yarns with extracted colorimetric reagents
Device Form Factor: Thread-based woven textile patches integrated at body sites (under-eye, armpit, forehead, chest, toes)
validation process: Colorimetric: spectrophotometry and optical imaging
Expected results: - pH sensing threads showed ~60 mV/pH (Nernstian response)
Potential applications: Wearable on-skin sweat monitors for diabetes management (glucose), hydration (electrolytes), skin health/wound monitoring (pH), fitness monitoring (sweat rate)
Limitations: - Limited analyte range when using off-the-shelf test strips (designed for urine, not sweat)
Procedure for building these devices:
1. Select mercerized cotton yarn (20/2 or 10/2). Clean with isopropanol and mordant with alum.
2. Extract reagents from commercial test strips (pH, glucose, cobalt chloride for sweat rate). Use solution to dye cotton threads.
3. For electrochemical threads: coat cotton with carbon ink (counter electrode), Ag/AgCl ink + PVB (reference electrode), and working electrodes with PANi (pH) or Prussian Blue + chitosan + glucose oxidase (glucose). Cure/dry as needed.
4. Weave threads into 2D/3D structures on a loom (plain weave, satin, twill, or double cloth) targeting body locations with high sweat density.
5. Attach woven patches on-skin using tape or adhesive.
6. Validate via spectrophotometer (colorimetric) or AFE IC (LMP91000, LMP91200) + microcontroller for electrochemical signals.
7. Test on human subjects for wearability and signal correlation.

Limitations: - Electrochemical testing setup (AFE ICs) less precise than benchtop potentiostats

Paper name: HoloChemie: Sustainable Fabrication of Soft Biochemical Holographic Devices for Ubiquitous Sensing
venue: ACM UIST (User Interface Software and Technology)
Sensing Target: Glucose (0.12–0.20 mM), Lactate (5–20 mM), CO₂ (400–800 ppm), pH extremes (1.5–2 and 12–13)
Type of sensing: Analyte-sensitive optical colorimetric sensing using biochemical and chemical assay layers read by LED–LDR array and spectrophotometry
Substrate: Alginate, agarose (2 % w/v), chromatography paper, tattoo paper, woven/non-woven fabrics (alginate preferred for transparency and flexibility)
Substrate sourcing: Alginate (Sigma W201502 / Amazon food-grade), agarose (Sigma A4718), chromatography paper (Sigma WHA3017820), tattoo paper (commercial), fabrics (Amazon)
Sensing layer materials: Glucose oxidase (GOx, Aspergillus niger), Lactate oxidase (LOx, Aerococcus viridans), potassium iodide (KI), starch, phosphate buffer (PBS), bromothymol blue (BTB), hibiscus anthocyanins extracted from hibiscus tea
Sensing materials Sourcing: Sigma Aldrich (GOx G7141 or G2133, LOx L9795, KI 221945, PBS P3619, BTB 114413); Amazon (hibiscus tea leaves, fabrics)
Fabrication process: Prepare soft substrate (e.g., alginate 1 : 25 : 1 alginate : glycerol  2% w/v: water; dry 8–10 h). For glucose sensing: mix 110 µL PBS + 20 µL GOx + 30 µL KI + 2 mg starch; for lactate sensing: mix 118 µL PBS + 32 µL LOx + 30 µL KI + 2 mg starch; for CO₂ sensing: dissolve 0.1 g BTB in 16 mL 0.01 N NaOH and dilute to 250 mL, drop-cast or brush onto substrate; for pH sensing: boil 3 g dried hibiscus tea leaves in 50 mL water for 15–20 min, cool, filter, and brush/spray extract on substrate. Dry all layers for ~20 min at room temperature before testing.
Device Form Factor: Flexible assay-coated thin films or patches applied on soft substrates for wearable or benchtop testing
validation process: Spectrophotometry (250–750 nm) shows distinct absorption peaks per analyte; LED–LDR setup collected 600 samples over 30 min at 50 Hz; Random Forest regression achieved R²: 0.87 (glucose), 0.91 (lactate), 0.94 (CO₂), 0.93 (pH)
Expected results: Color and transparency change correspond directly to analyte concentration; stable response for up to 10 hydration/drying cycles; accurate ML-based analyte prediction
Potential applications: Non-invasive sweat glucose and lactate sensing; CO₂ and pH monitoring for air quality and environmental diagnostics; sustainable biopolymer-based holographic color interfaces
Limitations: BTB layer gradually loses sensitivity after several CO₂ exposures (recoverable with 0.01 N NaOH); ambient light variation affects LED–LDR readings.
Procedure for building these devices: Prepare biopolymer substrate → mix enzyme-based or dye-based assay as described → drop-cast/brush/spray on substrate → dry 20 min → record optical response using LED–LDR array or spectrophotometer → retrain ML model on RGB/LDR data for quantitative estimation

Paper name: AnimSkin: Fabricating Epidermis with Interactive, Functional and Aesthetic Color Animation
venue: ACM DIS (Designing Interactive Systems)
Sensing Target: Touch sensing and thermal color animation
Type of sensing: Hybrid capacitive (touch input) + thermochromic (colorimetric actuation)
Substrate: Multi-layer silicone stack: transparent overlay + thermochromic silicone + conductive thread + ITO film + silicone base
Substrate sourcing: Silicone resin and curing agent (lab kits); thermochromic pigment (TK-CHEM SDS 38 °C red powder); conductive nylon thread (X-Silver, Adafruit/Taobao); ITO film (electronics vendors)
Sensing layer materials: Thermochromic pigment; silicone base; silver-coated nylon thread; copper wire; ITO film
Sensing materials Sourcing: TK-CHEM (thermochromic powder); Adafruit/Taobao (conductive yarn); local suppliers (ITO film, copper wire)
Fabrication process: Mix silicone + curing agent + thermochromic pigment (100:3:9) → cast 30–120 µm films → laser-cut pattern → embed conductive thread and copper wire → stack thermochromic + ITO + substrate layers → cure and bond with transparent overlay → apply body-safe adhesive
Device Form Factor: Thin (~0.38 mm) flexible on-skin film for interactive color animation and touch input
validation process: Capacitive ITO test (10 participants, overlay = 120–450 µm); durability/skin-friendly test (8 participants, 6 h wear at 3.3 V, 0.08 A); thermal actuation/color-change speed test
Expected results: Color change in 0.5–1 s at 3.3 V 0.08 A; stable touch sensing through ≤ 0.45 mm silicone; comfort 4–5 / 5; no irritation or circuit break
Potential applications: On-skin aesthetic notification; interactive tattoo; fashion/beauty tech application; wearable light or pattern control
Limitations: Activation above 38 °C; single-color thermochromic limitation; manual layering time; needs external 3.3 V power
Procedure for building these devices: Mix thermochromic pigment + silicone + curing agent → cast thin films → laser-cut pattern → lay conductive thread + copper wiring → add ITO film for touch sensing → stack and cure layers → apply adhesive → wear on skin and power at 3.3 V

Paper name: BioCosMe: Lip-based Cosmetics with Colorimetric Biosensors for Salivary Analysis using Deep Learning
venue: ACM ISWC (International Symposium on Wearable Computers)
Sensing Target: Salivary pH
Type of sensing: Colorimetric biosensing using natural anthocyanin pigment with deep learning (CNN, ResNet-18)
Substrate: Lip-based cosmetic substrates: lipstick, lip gloss, and lip tint
Substrate sourcing: Commercial cosmetic bases and food-grade materials (wax, glycerin, mica, TiO₂, cetyl octanoate, phenoxyethanol, polysorbate 80, red cabbage powder)
Sensing layer materials: Red cabbage (anthocyanin, 33.3%); silver mica (8.3%); TiO₂ (8.3%); cetyl octanoate (8.3%); primer adhesive (8.3%); for tint – water, glycerin, phenoxyethanol, polysorbate 80
Sensing materials Sourcing: Amazon; Sigma-Aldrich; cosmetic suppliers (food-grade and skin-safe materials)
Fabrication process: Heat cosmetic base to 175°F → add red cabbage and mica powders → stir 20 min at 165°F → pour into molds (lipstick/gloss) or bottles (tint) → chill 35–50°F → store at room temperature
Device Form Factor: Lipstick (solid), lip gloss (gel), and lip tint (aqueous) biosensors visually identical to commercial cosmetics
validation process: Artificial saliva (pH 5–8) tests; dataset of 2304 lip images (6 participants, 8 lighting conditions, 3 cameras); CNN training (ResNet-18, 100 epochs); user study (11 participants, 1-h sessions)
Expected results: CNN F1 = 0.92; RF = 0.39; SVM = 0.41; LOPO accuracy 37%; reusable up to 7 tests; usability mean 6/7; comfort 4.6/7; consistent pH detection with commercial strips
Potential applications: Everyday oral pH monitoring; cosmetic health biosensing; future glucose/cortisol extensions; beauty-biotech integration
Limitations: Lighting sensitivity; dataset limited (skin tones, participants); comfort issues (texture); not yet scalable; untested with eating/drinking
Procedure for building these devices: Prepare cosmetic base with red cabbage pigment → add additives (mica, TiO₂, cetyl octanoate) → heat, mix, pour into molds → cool and store → apply and test with pH buffers → collect lip images → train CNN → deploy mobile app for real-time lip-based pH sensing

Paper name: Exploring Biofoam as a Material for Tangible Interaction

Sensing Target: Pressure, force, temperature, UV light
Type of sensing: Hybrid resistive (pressure/force) and colorimetric (thermo/photochromic) sensing
Substrate: Biofoam (gelatin–glycerin–soap composite)
Substrate sourcing: DIY recipe adapted from FabTextiles “Bioplastics Cookbook”; ingredients (gelatin, glycerin, dish soap, water) available commercially (Amazon/local)
Sensing layer materials: Gelatin (24 g); Glycerin (24 mL); Water (300 mL); Dish soap (10 g); Stainless steel fibers (2.5 cm, 8 µm); Pine sap; Flax mucilage; Thermochromic/photochromic pigments; Natural powders (turmeric, walnut hull, charcoal)
Sensing materials Sourcing: Knox Gelatin (Amazon); stainless-steel roving fibers (e-textile suppliers); Jacquard Dye-Na-Flow pigments (Amazon); pine sap/flax seeds (local)
Fabrication process: Mix 300 mL water + 24 g gelatin → heat to 80 °C → add 24 mL glycerin → cook 2 h → add 10 g dish soap → whisk 90 s → fold in steel fibers → pour into molds → dry 24–48 h → optionally add pigments or natural additives
Device Form Factor: Cylindrical biofoam FSRs (5 × 2 cm); thin color-changing biofoam sheets (0.5–3 mm)
validation process: for wearables
Expected results: Density (0.13–0.65 g/cm³); compression (72% strain); FSR test 15–60 N (3.3 V, 330 Ω divider); recovery 3–5 s; biodegradation/recycling tests

Limitations: Sustainable haptic and sensing materials; color-changing jewelry/masks; biodegradable tactile sensors

column17: Mix gelatin, glycerin, water (80 °C) → add soap and whisk 90 s → fold in steel fibers → pour and dry 48 h → attach electrodes (copper taffeta) → connect via voltage divider → optionally add thermo/photochromic pigments for color feedback

Paper name: Biohybrid Devices: Prototyping Interactive Devices with Growable Materials
venue: ACM UIST (User Interface Software and Technology)
Sensing Target: Pressure, bending, touch, humidity, deformation
Type of sensing: Hybrid resistive (pressure/force), capacitive (touch/multi-touch), and humidity sensing
Substrate: Bacterial cellulose (BC) biofilm grown via kombucha fermentation
Substrate sourcing: DIY kombucha medium (tea, sugar, vinegar, SCOBY); locally available or commercial kits (Amazon, Carrefour Bio)
Sensing layer materials: Conductive textiles (EeonTex COM-14112); Velostat; Polyimide films; Carbon-doped beeswax (10% Vulcan XC72R); Graphite (ProGraphite); Conductive PLA (Protopasta); Conductive yarn (Datastretch 1468-SI); Starch-based conductive paste (40% graphite + CléoBio bioglue)
Sensing materials Sourcing: Eeonyx; Protopasta; Sigma-Aldrich (carbon black); ProGraphite (Germany); CléoBio (France); Adafruit (LEDs/Neopixel); Amazon (conductive yarn); Kombucha culture (local/online)
Fabrication process: Grow BC films (7–20 days @ 24–25 °C) → embed electronics after 5 days (“Grow Around”) → wash and dry (3–7 days or 4–12 h @ 80 °C) → integrate via Layering / Imbuing / Slicing → laser engrave conductive traces with graphite paste → assemble and seal
Device Form Factor: Biohybrid BC-based FSRs, capacitive pads, humidity sensors, and wearable interfaces (bracelets, controllers, SMA-actuated devices)
validation process: Resistance range 0.6–15.4 kΩ; SNR 42–73 dB; humidity range 215 kΩ–2 MΩ; graphite traces 39 Ω/□ (10 mm); copper/silver growth inhibition tests
Expected results: 13 interactive samples; 170+ BC cultures; 7 embedding techniques across growth/stabilization/inanimate phases; functional wearables with LEDs and SMA actuators
Potential applications: Sustainable bio-integrated wearables; shape-changing soft robotics; biodegradable controllers; DIY educational bio-HCI materials
Limitations: Slow growth (7–20 days); copper/silver toxicity; humidity degradation; laser damage; manual drying affects reproducibility
Procedure for building these devices: Prepare kombucha medium → grow BC (7–20 days) → embed electronics at day 5 → dry → integrate via Layering/Imbuing/Slicing → laser engrave graphite circuits → attach microcontroller (Arduino/Nano) → waterproof and test sensing response

Paper name: Designing Direct Interactions with Bioluminescent Algae
venue: ACM DIS (Designing Interactive Systems)
Sensing Target: Mechanical touch, vibration, and movement triggering bioluminescence
Type of sensing: Bio-optical / mechano-chemical sensing (light emission via luciferin–luciferase reaction)
Substrate: Living marine dinoflagellate cultures (*Pyrocystis fusiformis*)
Substrate sourcing: PyroFarms (P. fusiformis culture); Fritz Aquatics (F/2 media Parts A & B); Instant Ocean marine salt (PetSmart); distilled water (local stores)
Sensing layer materials: Living algal cells as sensing and emitting medium; no synthetic sensing layer
Sensing materials Sourcing: PyroFarms (living culture); Fritz Aquatics Pro; Instant Ocean; local hardware suppliers (LEDs, timer, enclosure)

Device Form Factor: Living liquid medium in closed, porous, or open vessels for light-emitting interactions
validation process: Light intensity measured with BT-881D lux meter; closed env. = 0.137 lux (2.66 s), porous = 0.033 lux (0.89 s), open = 0.087 lux (2.35 s); hue via Photoshop; LED control = 133.9 lux
Expected results: Instant blue-green glow on motion; longer glow in closed setups; dissipates within seconds; culture stable under 12/12 light cycle and gentle aeration

Procedure for building these devices: Prepare marine medium → add F/2 nutrients and starter algae → maintain 12/12 light cycle at 18–22 °C → expand to 20 L → design interaction containers → stimulate manually and record bioluminescent output

Paper name: BioSparks: Jewelry as Electrochemical Sweat Biosensors with Modular, Repurposing and Interchangeable Approaches
venue: ACM UbiComp/ISWC Adjunct
Sensing Target: Glucose in sweat
Type of sensing: Electrochemical chronoamperometry (three-electrode configuration)
Substrate: Sterling silver jewelry case with replaceable 3D-printed silicone insert
Substrate sourcing: Silver (925 sterling) from Rio Grande; FormLabs Flexible 80A resin; leather straps and epoxy gems (Amazon/jewelry suppliers)
Sensing layer materials: Sterling silver electrodes (working, reference, counter); Glucose oxidase enzyme and cross-linker (Zimmer & Peacock); Biosensor barrier solution (Zimmer & Peacock); Silicone insert (Flexible 80A resin)

Device Form Factor: Modular wearable jewelry biosensor (bracelet, necklace, belt) with interchangeable electrodes and replaceable casing

Paper name: Chitosan Biofilm Actuators – Humidity Responsive Materials for Sustainable Interaction Design
venue: ACM TEI (Tangible, Embedded, and Embodied Interaction)
Sensing Target: Humidity (relative humidity 60–90%)
Type of sensing: Passive hygroscopic actuation (moisture-driven bending)
Substrate: Chitosan biofilm and woven cotton (bilayer)
Substrate sourcing: Chitosan powder (Sigma-Aldrich/Amazon); vinegar (5% acetic acid); distilled water; textile-grade cotton fabric
Sensing layer materials: Chitosan powder (5 wt%); vinegar (50%); water (50%); optional flax mucilage or pine sap for strength; food coloring for visual variation
Sensing materials Sourcing: Sigma-Aldrich (chitosan); local grocery vinegar; distilled water; cotton textile suppliers
Fabrication process: Mix chitosan (5 wt%) with 50% vinegar + 50% water → heat to 60 °C → pour 20 mL into 80×80×4 mm mold → dry 6 h at 55 °C → optionally coat cotton one-sided for bilayer → dry fully to form humidity-actuated film
Device Form Factor: Thin (0.3–0.5 mm) humidity-responsive films and cotton–chitosan bilayers for haptic, display, or textile prototypes

Paper name: ChromaLipSense: Lipstick-Based Biosensors for Metabolic Monitoring
venue: Wearables Collective (University of California, Davis)
Sensing Target: Salivary pH (5.5–8.0)
Type of sensing: Colorimetric biosensing (anthocyanin-based color shift analyzed by deep learning, ResNet-18/50)
Substrate: Cosmetic-grade lipstick base (castor oil, beeswax, carnauba wax, olive oil, cetyl alcohol)
Substrate sourcing: TKB Trading (lipstick base); cosmetic suppliers (Sigma, Amazon); food-grade red cabbage powder (grocery)
Sensing layer materials: Red cabbage powder (anthocyanin pigment); cetyl octanoate; titanium dioxide (non-nano); silver mica; primer adhesive (stearic acid + PVP); acrylate copolymer
Sensing materials Sourcing: TKB Trading (cosmetic base); Sigma-Aldrich/Amazon (additives); food-grade suppliers (red cabbage powder)
Fabrication process: Mix 4 parts lipstick base + 1 part cetyl octanoate + 1 part TiO₂ + 1 part primer adhesive → heat to 185 °F (10 min) → add acrylate copolymer + silver mica + red cabbage at 175 °F → stir 5 min → pour into molds (9 mm) → chill at 35 °F for 10 min → store at room temp
Device Form Factor: Lipstick-based biosensor for salivary pH monitoring applied on lips or silicone lip models
validation process: Tested on 5 buffer pH levels (5.5–8.0) using NaH₂PO₄/acetic acid; images captured under 8 lighting conditions (2200–6500 K) with Canon EOS R & Pixel 6; 4 participants + artificial lips dataset (~40 images × 5 pH × 8 lighting × 2 devices); ResNet-18/50 trained 50 epochs, lr 0.0001, ADAM optimizer
Expected results: ResNet-18 & 50 models achieved 96.88% test accuracy; clear hue transition red→purple→blue; stable color shifts across lighting conditions; reproducible results in lab trials
Potential applications: Cosmetic-integrated biosensing for oral/metabolic monitoring; adaptable to eyeliner, foundation, or tattoo sensors
Limitations: Small dataset (n = 4 participants); anthocyanin instability; lighting sensitivity; single-analyte limitation
Procedure for building these devices: Mix and heat lipstick ingredients at 185 °F → add mica + anthocyanin pigment → pour and cool in molds → apply and expose to pH 5.5–8.0 → capture images under multiple lights → train ResNet for classification

Paper name: Designing with Alganyl
venue: ACM TEI (Tangible, Embedded, and Embodied Interaction)
Sensing Target: UV light and temperature
Type of sensing: Colorimetric (photochromic and thermochromic pigments embedded in bioplastic)
Substrate: Alganyl bioplastic (agar–glycerin composite)
Substrate sourcing: Food-grade agar powder, glycerin, and water (Sigma/Amazon/local stores)
Sensing layer materials: Photochromic pigment (cream→pink under UV); thermochromic pigment (blue↔white with temperature); optional activated charcoal for conductive circuits; food/natural dyes for color customization
Sensing materials Sourcing: Chromatic Technologies Inc. (CTI); Sigma/Amazon (agar, glycerin); local sources (dyes, vinegar)
Fabrication process: Mix 50 mL water + 2 g agar + 3 g glycerin → boil (~2 min microwave or 10 min stovetop) → add 0.25 g pigment → pour on flat surface → dry 24–72 h → cut or heat-seal → optionally recycle by re-cooking 3:10 in water
Device Form Factor: Flexible Alganyl film (0.5–1 mm thick) shaped into bracelets, necklaces, or interactive surfaces
validation process: UV pen and sunlight tests (photochromic: cream→pink); heat tests (thermochromic: purple→red at ~35 °C); mechanical testing (13% elongation, 12.5 MPa); biodegradation 97% mass loss in 60 days at 40 °C

Procedure for building these devices: Mix agar, glycerin, and water (2:3:50 ratio) → heat to dissolve → add pigment → pour and dry 24–72 h → shape and seal → expose to UV/heat to observe color change → recycle by re-cooking scraps

Paper name: EarthTones: Chemical Sensing Powders to Detect and Display Environmental Hazards through Color Variation
venue: ACM CHI Extended Abstracts
Sensing Target: Carbon Monoxide (CO), Ultraviolet (UV), Ozone (O₃)

Paper name: EcoPatches: Maker-Friendly Chemical-Based UV Sensing

Paper name: EcoThreads: Prototyping Biodegradable E-Textiles Through Thread-Based Fabrication
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems

Paper name: ECSkin: Tessellating Electrochromic Films for Reconfigurable On-skin Displays
venue: Proceedings of the ACM on Interactive, Mobile, Wearable and Ubiquitous Technologies (IMWUT) / UbiComp

Paper name: ecSkin: Low-Cost Fabrication of Epidermal Electrochemical Sensors for Detecting Biomarkers in Sweat
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
Sensing Target: Glucose and cortisol in sweat
Type of sensing: Electrochemical sensing using printed conductive inks, characterized with cyclic voltammetry (CV) and chronoamperometry, followed by machine learning-based concentration prediction
Substrate: PET sheet (for final biosensing), tattoo paper, and silicone sheet (tested for compatibility)
Substrate sourcing: Generic lab-supply PET sheets, Silhouette tattoo paper (craft stores), silicone sheets (Amazon)
Sensing layer materials: Graphite + alkyd wood varnish (1:2 ratio) + 5 wt% powdered imitation gold leaf additive (V2 formulation); alternative oleogel ink (graphite + beeswax + olive oil); reference electrode: Ag/AgCl silver ink

Procedure for building these devices: Formulate varnish-based ink (4 g graphite + 2 g varnish + 0.3 g gold leaf + 5–7 mL acetone, stir 85 °C 15 min) → stencil-print Ag/AgCl reference → cure 65 °C 15 min → print working and counter → dry 6–8 h → test CV/CA in artificial sweat → optionally train Random Forest regressor for glucose/cortisol concentration prediction

Paper name: ElectroDermis: Fully Untethered, Stretchable, and Highly-Customizable Electronic Bandages

Paper name: E-seed: Shape-Changing Interfaces That Self-Drill

Paper name: Sketch&Stitch: Interactive Embroidery for E-Textiles

Paper name: Flavorium: An Exploration of Flavobacteria’s Living Aesthetics for Living Color Interfaces

Paper name: Sensitive Colorimetric Sensors for Visual Detection of Carbon Dioxide and Sulfur Dioxide
venue: Journal of Materials Chemistry A
Sensing Target: Carbon dioxide (CO₂) and sulfur dioxide (SO₂)

Device Form Factor: Porous colorimetric pellets for visual gas detection
validation process: CO₂: <10 s response at 500 ppm, 5 s at ≥1500 ppm; SO₂: visible at 0.2 % v/v; reversible in 15–20 s under air/N₂; stable ≥1–3 months depending on grafting
Expected results: Color change purple ↔ yellow (cresol red) or blue ↔ green (BTB) upon exposure to CO₂/SO₂; reversible and visible to the naked eye
Potential applications: Low-cost visual CO₂ and SO₂ monitoring for air-quality, flue gas, or confined-space safety detection
Limitations: Requires dry conditions; limited durability under humidity; amine evaporation; dye photobleaching over repeated cycles
Procedure for building these devices: Soak γ-Al₂O₃ pellets in tertiary amino alcohol → dry → immerse in dye solution → dry → expose to CO₂/SO₂ → regenerate by N₂ purge or mild heating; optional GPMS silane grafting for longer shelf life

Paper name: Isolation and Characterization of Anthocyanins from Hibiscus sabdariffa Flowers

Paper name: Prototyping Soft Devices with Interactive Bioplastics

Paper name: iSkin: Flexible, Stretchable and Visually Customizable On-Body Touch Sensors for Mobile Computing

Paper name: Like a Second Skin: Understanding How Epidermal Devices Affect Human Tactile Perception
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
Sensing Target: Tactile perception (sensitivity, spatial acuity, roughness discrimination)

Substrate: PDMS (Sylgard 184, OE-6550) and temporary tattoo film substrates

Sensing layer materials: Sylgard 184 (E = 2.7 MPa) medium rigidity ~1.3×10⁻⁷ Nm; OE-6550 (E = 5.1 MPa) high rigidity ~1.2×10⁻⁵ Nm; tattoo paper (E ≈ 1 GPa) low rigidity ~1.7×10⁻⁹ Nm; PDMS adhesive MG7-1010 (Dow Corning)

validation process: 16 participants (9F, mean age 27.4) tested across 3 experiments: tactile sensitivity, spatial acuity, roughness discrimination; sensitivity threshold increased 34.7 % (Low), 97.6 % (Med), 221.6 % (High); roughness discrimination error +487.7 % (High rigidity)

Potential applications: Design guidelines for epidermal and on-skin interfaces optimizing tactile fidelity vs durability
Limitations: No vibrotactile or thermal tests; limited to PDMS and tattoo materials; small participant group
Procedure for building these devices: Mix and cure PDMS (Sylgard 184 or OE-6550) → apply adhesive → cure → cut 4.5 cm patches → measure rigidity → apply to fingertip/hand → test tactile sensitivity (Von Frey), 2-point discrimination, and roughness recognition

Paper name: Integrating Living Organisms in Devices to Implement Care-based Interactions
venue: ACM UIST (User Interface Software and Technology)
Sensing Target: Heart rate (enabled only when organism is conductive)
Type of sensing: Bioelectrical sensing using Physarum polycephalum as a living conductive bridge controlling a heart rate sensor
Substrate: Acrylic housing with magnetized wells and transparent lid for slime mold growth
Substrate sourcing: Acrylic sheet (laser-cut), neodymium magnets, PLA or resin 3D-printed enclosure
Sensing layer materials: Living slime mold Physarum polycephalum cultured on oat flakes and water, bridging electrodes as a bio-conductive element
Sensing materials Sourcing: Carolina Biological Supply or Slime Mould Collective (Slimoco); Quaker oats; distilled water; neodymium magnets (Amazon)
Fabrication process: Laser-cut acrylic wells → insert magnets and electrodes → seed dried Physarum in one well + oats + water in both → seal with transparent cover → connect to smartwatch circuit (Seeeduino Xiao, MAX3010 HR sensor, SSD1306 OLED, LRA motor, RV-3028 RTC, 200 mAh Li-Po) → maintain humidity and feed oats twice daily → observe bridge growth and conductivity
Device Form Factor: Smartwatch platform integrating living organism as part of electrical circuit
validation process: Conductive bridge forms in ≈12.7 ± 3.05 h; dries ≈16 ± 9.6 h; regrows ≈10.3 ± 4.9 h; resistance < 3.5 MΩ when active; human study (n=5, 9–14 days) showed users developed care and empathy toward device
Expected results: Heart rate sensing active only when Physarum bridge is alive and conductive; demonstrates “care-based interaction” linking biological vitality to sensing functionality
Potential applications: Wearable bio-interactive systems promoting care, empathy, and sustainable relationships with living devices
Limitations: Requires constant feeding and moisture; limited environmental tolerance; variable growth speed; short operational lifespan; bioethics and contamination risks
Procedure for building these devices: Laser-cut acrylic enclosure → add magnets/electrodes → seed Physarum and oats → connect to smartwatch circuit → feed water/oats daily → monitor bridge conductivity enabling or disabling HR sensor; repeat growth/drying cycles for testing

Paper name: LivingLoom: Investigating Human–Plant Symbiosis Through Integrating Living Plants into (E-)Textiles
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
Sensing Target: Moisture, light, humidity, and touch sensing within plant-integrated textiles
Type of sensing: Capacitive, moisture, and environmental sensing using seed-embedded hydrogel yarns and conductive textile structures
Substrate: Seed-integrated hydrogel yarns woven into cotton, twill, or double-weave textile structures
Substrate sourcing: Hydrogel polymer base and yarns fabricated in-lab; microgreen seeds (chia, broccoli) sourced commercially; cotton/twill fabrics from Joann Fabrics or equivalent
Sensing layer materials: Hydrogel yarns containing microgreen seeds; conductive threads interwoven for capacitive sensing; flexible tubing (ID 1 mm, OD 2 mm) for irrigation; disc vibration motor and microcontroller for feedback
Sensing materials Sourcing: Amazon (microgreen seeds); McMaster-Carr (tubing 5233K111); SparkFun/Adafruit (pump, vibration motor, microcontroller); Joann Fabrics (base textiles)
Fabrication process: Wet-spin hydrogel yarns with seeds → weave into textile forms → integrate conductive threads and irrigation tubing → attach 5 V peristaltic pump and vibration motor → connect to microcontroller → maintain daily watering and 6 h light exposure during 10-day growth cycle
Device Form Factor: Living textile platform with integrated plant growth and capacitive touch interaction
validation process: 10-day growth cycle maintained; sprouts germinate within 2–3 days; capacitive sensing via chia sprout electrodes responsive to touch; self-watering validated with peristaltic pump; user study (n=10) confirmed emotional engagement and care motivation

Potential applications: Wearable living textiles, bio-aesthetic eco-fashion, care-based interactive systems, sustainable HCI prototypes
Limitations: Requires daily watering and sunlight; fragile during early growth; sprouts dry under low humidity; electronics limited by moisture exposure
Procedure for building these devices: Wet-spin hydrogel yarns with seeds → weave into textile (double/waffle weave) → integrate conductive threads and tubing → connect pump and controller → grow 10 days under sunlight → test touch sensing and self-watering performance

Paper name: Lotio: Lotion-Mediated Interaction with an Electronic Skin-Worn Display
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
Sensing Target: Lotion presence, lotion type, and touch events on skin
Type of sensing: Resistive sensing and electrochromic display actuation using PEDOT:PSS films activated by applied lotion as electrolyte
Substrate: Cellulose acetate film or 3M Micropore surgical tape (biodegradable, skin-safe, lotion-permeable)
Substrate sourcing: Commercial cellulose acetate sheets; 3M Micropore surgical tape (medical stores, Amazon)
Sensing layer materials: PEDOT:PSS mixed with DMSO (7:3 ratio) as conductive and electrochromic layer; copper tape for connections; lotion (sunscreen, moisturizer, ointment, sanitizer) as electrolyte
Sensing materials Sourcing: Sigma-Aldrich (PEDOT:PSS, DMSO); 3M (Micropore tape); Adafruit/SparkFun (Arduino, ATtiny85); retail pharmacy lotions
Fabrication process: Mix PEDOT:PSS : DMSO (7:3) → airbrush onto acetate/tape on 120 °C plate (~1 µm film) → dry → laser-cut pattern → transfer to skin → connect copper leads → apply lotion (~1 µm) to activate electrochromic response → observe color change and current response
Device Form Factor: Electrochromic skin-worn display activated by lotion application
validation process: 1–5 V operation; color switching <3 s for sunscreen/moisturizer; bistable color >10 min; dry vs lotion touch differentiated by ~30 µA current; unique current/time profiles for each lotion type
Expected results: Visible, low-power, color-changing skin display responsive to lotion application and touch; self-care feedback through electrochromic color modulation
Potential applications: Ambient skin displays, sunscreen reminders, cosmetic computing, hydration or medication feedback patches
Limitations: PEDOT:PSS layer fragile under alcohol sanitizers; sweat can cause false activation; requires external microcontroller and power source; limited scalability
Procedure for building these devices: Mix PEDOT:PSS + DMSO (7:3) → airbrush on substrate at 120 °C → dry and laser-cut → transfer to skin → attach copper leads → apply lotion to activate color change → test lotion differentiation and bistability

Paper name: MediKnit: A Textile-Based Physiological Sensing Framework for Wellness and Care Applications
venue: ACM IMWUT (Proceedings of the ACM on Interactive, Mobile, Wearable and Ubiquitous Technologies)
Sensing Target: Heart rate, respiration, touch, and body movement
Type of sensing: Multimodal bioimpedance, capacitive, and resistive sensing using knitted textile electrodes and conductive yarn structures
Substrate: Knitted spandex–cotton blended fabric with interwoven conductive and insulating yarns
Substrate sourcing: Base fabric from Hohenstein Institute or commercial knitting mills; conductive yarns (silver-plated nylon) from Shieldex
Sensing layer materials: Conductive yarns (Shieldex 117/17 dtex 2-ply silver-plated nylon); insulating polyester/cotton yarns; Ecoflex 00-30 silicone coating; snap connectors or conductive threads for MCU linkage
Sensing materials Sourcing: Shieldex (conductive yarns); Smooth-On (Ecoflex); Arduino Nano 33 BLE or ADS1292 AFE (Adafruit/SparkFun); commercial textile mills
Fabrication process: Design knit pattern (single jersey, rib, purl) → knit using Shima Seiki SWG061N machine → integrate conductive yarn electrodes at target zones → apply thin Ecoflex coating → sew snap buttons/conductive threads → connect to ADS1292 analog front-end or Arduino BLE → calibrate respiration and heart rate channels

validation process: Respiration: impedance Δ ~0.15 Ω (inhale/exhale); heart rate: 93.4 % correlation with ECG; capacitive touch SNR 28.3; stretch linear up to 35 % (ΔR/R₀ ≈ 0.48); washable up to 20 cycles (<10 % loss)

Procedure for building these devices: Knit spandex–cotton fabric with conductive yarns → coat Ecoflex → attach connectors → link to ADS1292 or Arduino → calibrate respiration and HR → test touch and stretch → wash test and validate comfort/durability

Paper name: Multi-Touch Skin: A Thin and Flexible Multi-Touch Sensor for On-Skin Input
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
Sensing Target: Touch and gesture sensing on skin
Type of sensing: Mutual-capacitance sensing using flexible printed transmitter and receiver electrodes for multi-touch input

Sensing materials Sourcing: Mitsubishi Paper Mill (silver ink, PET film); Gwent Group (PEDOT:PSS, dielectric pastes); 3M (Z-axis tape); Amazon (tattoo paper)

validation process: SNR = 31.6–52.6 (shielded) vs 2.4–5 (unshielded); accuracy 0.72–1.49 mm across flat/wrist/finger; resolves 2 touches at ~7 mm spacing; stable at 100 Hz update rate

Limitations: Brittle dielectric pastes prone to cracking; gold leaf fragile for small electrodes; accuracy drops on extreme curvature; limited connector flexibility
Procedure for building these devices: Screen print silver/PEDOT transmitter and receiver layers on tattoo paper → add PVC dielectric → stack and align → bond with tattoo adhesive → connect via FFC to MTCH6303 controller → test multi-touch accuracy and SNR on body

Paper name: Myco-Accessories: Sustainable Wearables with Biodegradable Materials
venue: ACM International Symposium on Wearable Computers (ISWC)

Sensing layer materials: Mycelium substrate (fungal composite); embedded LEDs, coin batteries, Neopixel rings, switches laminated between two mycelium layers
Sensing materials Sourcing: Grow.bio (mycelium substrate); Adafruit/SparkFun (LEDs, Neopixels, batteries); Amazon (glycerin); homemade cornstarch glue
Fabrication process: Activate mycelium kit (flour + water) → incubate 7–10 days → mold + incubate 4–8 days → peel + flatten → cure with glycerin (1–2 days) → embed LED circuit between two mycelium layers → glue with cornstarch → laser cut/stitch → dry and test illumination
Device Form Factor: Biodegradable illuminated wearable accessories with reusable electronics
validation process: Mycelium skins grown 30–40 days; thickness 0.5–2 mm; flexible after glycerin treatment; electronics functional and reusable; biodegrades within ~90 days after composting

Procedure for building these devices: Grow mycelium substrate → flatten and cure with glycerin → embed and laminate circuit between two skins → glue with cornstarch → laser cut + stitch → dry → test illumination → reuse electronics and compost mycelium

Paper name: Nail pHolish: Sensing Hand-Fluid Interactions Through Biocosmetic Interfaces
venue: ACM International Symposium on Wearable Computers (ISWC)
Sensing Target: pH of bodily fluids and environmental liquids
Type of sensing: Colorimetric pH sensing using anthocyanin-based biocosmetic nail polish with optical readout via spectrophotometer or app
Substrate: Water-based nail polish applied on natural or artificial fingernails
Substrate sourcing: Commercial water-based nail polish base; cosmetic-grade red cabbage powder (anthocyanins) and non-nano titanium dioxide pigments
Sensing layer materials: Red cabbage powder (anthocyanins) as pH-sensitive pigment; titanium dioxide for opacity; nail polish base with styrene/acrylates copolymer, polyacrylic acid, propylene glycol, phenoxyethanol, caprylyl glycol; optional top coat
Sensing materials Sourcing: Sigma-Aldrich (red cabbage pigment, TiO₂); DIY cosmetic suppliers (nail polish base); Nix Sensor Ltd. (Spectro 2 colorimeter)
Fabrication process: Grind 0.1 g TiO₂ + 0.2 g red cabbage powder → mix with 3 g nail polish base → stir 5 min → transfer to bottle → apply 1 coat → air dry 2 h → expose to pH 5–8.5 liquids (color change pink → purple → blue-green) → test reversibility under repeated cycles → record optical data via spectrophotometer
Device Form Factor: Color-changing pH-sensitive nail polish for fluid interaction detection
validation process: pH range 5–8.5; reversible color transitions (pink ↔ blue-green); wear duration up to 72 h; pH measurement accuracy ±0.2; maintains color under daily use (washing, cooking); user usability rating 6.8/7
Expected results: Visible and reversible pH-dependent color change integrated into nail polish; detects acidity of fluids via naked-eye or app-based readout
Potential applications: Health monitoring (oral, sweat, reproductive fluids); environmental acidity detection (rain, beverages); cosmetic and educational bio-HCI applications
Limitations: Pigment fading after multiple cycles; 2–3 day wear limit (water-based base); limited to pH detection only; thickness sensitivity on curved nails
Procedure for building these devices: Grind pigment + TiO₂ → mix with nail polish base → bottle → apply on nail → dry 2 h → test under different fluids (pH 5–8) → measure RGB via spectrometer → recalibrate color library for app readout

Paper name: Organic Primitives: Synthesis and Design of pH-Reactive Materials Using Molecular I/O for Sensing, Actuation, and Interaction
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
Sensing Target: pH of liquids and biological fluids
Type of sensing: Colorimetric, olfactory, and shape-based molecular sensing and actuation using biopolymer films responsive to pH
Substrate: Kappa-carrageenan, sodium alginate, and chitosan biopolymer films
Substrate sourcing: Food-grade sodium alginate, kappa-carrageenan, chitosan, citric acid, sodium bicarbonate, and calcium sulfate from culinary/chemical suppliers
Sensing layer materials: Anthocyanin pigment (0.1% w/v) for color sensing; vanillin (0.12% v/v) for odor actuation; chitosan (4% w/v in 3% acetic acid) for swelling actuation; calcium sulfate crosslinker; acids/bases for pH control (2–10)
Sensing materials Sourcing: Modernist Pantry (alginate, carrageenan); Sigma-Aldrich (vanillin, chitosan, calcium sulfate, acetic acid); Enasco (anthocyanin)
Fabrication process: Dissolve selected biopolymer (1.5–4% w/v) → add dopant (anthocyanin/vanillin/chitosan) → cast into mold → dry 12–24 h → crosslink alginate with calcium sulfate (15:100) → test under pH 2–10 solutions → record responses (color, odor, shape) → optionally combine primitives for multi-modal response
Device Form Factor: Edible and biodegradable molecular materials acting as pH-responsive sensors and actuators
validation process: Color change (pH 2 red → pH 10 green, 50–90 s); odor ON (pH 2–8), OFF (pH 9–10, <5 s); chitosan bending in 10 min at pH 3–8; user recognition of odor intensity accurate across pH range
Expected results: Soft, self-contained materials that sense and actuate through molecular mechanisms without electronics; biocompatible and reversible within moderate pH range
Potential applications: Environmental pH sensing, edible cosmetics, body-fluid monitoring, food interfaces, and interactive packaging
Limitations: Requires liquid pH input; limited reversibility at extreme pH; odor loss over repeated cycles; 12–24 h drying; humidity affects durability
Procedure for building these devices: Prepare alginate/carrageenan/chitosan base → mix dopant (anthocyanin/vanillin) → cast film → dry → crosslink → expose to pH 2–10 → observe color, odor, or shape response → combine primitives for hybrid output

Paper name: PhysioSkin: Rapid Fabrication of Skin-Conformal Physiological Interfaces
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
Sensing Target: Surface electromyography (sEMG), electrocardiography (ECG), and electrodermal activity (EDA)
Type of sensing: Bioelectrical and capacitive sensing using digitally fabricated ultra-thin printed electrodes on skin or textiles
Substrate: Tattoo paper, thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU), PDMS, PET film, and textile transfer film (SKULLPAPER)
Substrate sourcing: Tattoo paper (SUNNYSCOPA, Amazon); TPU film (3M/custom suppliers); PDMS (Dow Corning Sylgard 184); PET (Mitsubishi); textile transfer film (SKULLPAPER Premium)
Sensing layer materials: Silver nanoparticle ink (Cabot CCI-300); PEDOT:PSS conductive polymer; PVP dielectric (5–6 layers); soft skin adhesive (MG7-1010); optional copper tape/FPC connectors

Limitations: SNR below medical grade for ECG; PET variant non-stretchable; PDMS requires plasma pretreatment; adhesion weakens under sweat or prolonged wear
Procedure for building these devices: Inkjet-print silver ink on chosen substrate → heat cure → add PEDOT:PSS + PVP dielectric → apply skin adhesive → laser cut → transfer to skin → connect via FPC → calibrate and record EMG/ECG/EDA signals

Paper name: SCOBY Breastplate: Slowly Growing a Microbial Interface
venue: ACM Tangible, Embedded, and Embodied Interaction (TEI)
Sensing Target: Touch intensity (light, medium, heavy) through microbial biofilm
Type of sensing: Capacitive sensing using activated carbon–coated SCOBY biofilm with LED feedback
Substrate: Dried microbial cellulose (SCOBY) layers grown in sweet tea medium over mannequin molds
Substrate sourcing: DIY-grown SCOBY from GT’s Kombucha starter; sugar, black tea, and olive/coconut oil from grocery sources
Sensing layer materials: Activated carbon paint for conductivity; SCOBY cellulose film as dielectric; waterproof LED strip; Adafruit Feather 32u4 Basic Proto; 3.7 V 150 mAh Li-ion battery
Sensing materials Sourcing: GT’s Kombucha (starter culture); Adafruit (Feather, LEDs, battery); Sigma-Aldrich/Amazon (activated carbon); food-grade tea, sugar, oils (supermarket)
Fabrication process: Brew 3.3 L sweet tea + 200 g sugar + 3 tea bags → cool → add 500 mL kombucha starter → incubate 3 weeks/layer (5 mm) → harvest and oil-treat SCOBY → dry 2–5 days → stack 4 layers (shape, support, LEDs, conductive SCOBY) → laser cut (Epilog M2, 30/70) → connect to Feather microcontroller → map touch intensity to LED PWM brightness
Device Form Factor: Grown microbial interface wearable with capacitive sensing and illumination
validation process: Tensile strength 6.84–8.06 MPa; elongation 3.83–27.13 %; detects 3 pressure levels; LED brightness mapped to touch; biodegrades 96 % (plain) / 84 % (conductive) in 30 days
Expected results: Biodegradable touch-sensitive wearable integrating SCOBY growth with digital interactivity; explores slow, sustainable fabrication and living material HCI
Potential applications: Sustainable microbial wearables, slow design education, biodegradable fashion, DIYBio interfaces
Limitations: Slow growth (13 weeks total for 4 layers); material variability; fragile in humidity; limited capacitance uniformity
Procedure for building these devices: Brew tea + sugar + starter → grow SCOBY 3 weeks/layer → oil-treat + dry → mold on mannequin → embed LEDs + carbon SCOBY → connect microcontroller → test LED brightness by touch → compost after use

Paper name: Silicone Devices: A Scalable DIY Approach for Fabricating Self-Contained Multi-Layered Soft Circuits Using Microfluidics
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
Sensing Target: Touch, proximity, pressure, and strain sensing
Type of sensing: Capacitive and resistive sensing using multi-layer PDMS circuits with Galinstan liquid-metal microchannels and embedded components
Substrate: Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) silicone, cast in multi-layer configuration with embedded components
Substrate sourcing: PDMS (Silicones & More Transparent 15 Fast); vinyl masks; acrylic buildplates; silicone primer (BISON); Galinstan liquid metal (Sigma-Aldrich)
Sensing layer materials: Galinstan (gallium–indium–tin alloy) for conductive channels; PDMS as insulating matrix; silicone primer for adhesion; copper pads, SMD ICs, LEDs, batteries, and microcontrollers embedded within layers

validation process: Resistive stability: +0.16 Ω (5.7 %) after 1000 cycles at 200 % strain; strain range up to 400 %; capacitive touch range 0–7 cm; strain sensing 190–650 Ω (0–150 %); pressure tunable by PDMS thickness (Shore A 15–40); workshop users fabricated devices <4 h
Expected results: Durable and reconfigurable soft circuit platform with conductive microchannels for touch, proximity, pressure, and strain sensing
Potential applications: DIY stretchable wearables, soft robotics, interactive surfaces, and health-monitoring prototypes
Limitations: Manual process (1–4 h fabrication); thick (~1 mm); opaque Galinstan; precision required for layer transfer and VIA filling
Procedure for building these devices: Design circuit → cast PDMS layers → laser-cut masks → paint Galinstan → seal with PDMS → form VIAs → embed LEDs/microcontroller → cure and test strain and capacitive response

Paper name: SkinMarks: Enabling Interactions on Body Landmarks Using Conformal Skin Electronics
venue: ACM CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems
Sensing Target: Touch, squeeze, and bend sensing on skin and body landmarks
Type of sensing: Capacitive, resistive, and electroluminescent multimodal sensing using printed PEDOT:PSS and silver inks on temporary tattoo substrates

Paper name: Skinergy: Machine-Embroidered Silicone-Textile Composites as On-Skin Self-Powered Input Sensors

Paper name: SkinMorph: Texture-Tunable On-Skin Interface Through Thin, Programmable Gel
venue: ACM International Symposium on Wearable Computers (ISWC)
Sensing Target: Programmable texture and stiffness modulation on skin
Type of sensing: Thermally induced soft-to-stiff actuation using Joule-heated NiCr wires embedded in hydrogel-silicone composite
